title: 108_s239
content: The Act titled "Trauma Care Systems Planning and Development Act of 2003" is cited as the short title. The findings section follows. Congress finds that there is a history of cooperation between the Federal Government and State governments in developing comprehensive emergency medical services. Trauma is a leading cause of death in the US, with significant costs associated with traumatic injuries, particularly from motor vehicle-related incidents. Improving emergency medical services can reduce trauma-related deaths and is crucial for homeland defense. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS. Section 1201 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the collection, compilation, and dissemination of information on trauma care and emergency medical services, with special consideration for rural areas. In amending Section 1201 of the Public Health Service Act, the bill aims to enhance each State's trauma care capabilities, promote consistent trauma data collection, and improve emergency medical services. The bill amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a Clearinghouse on Trauma Care and Emergency Medical Services, redesignating sections and improving trauma care in rural areas by including advanced trauma life support in model curricula. The bill amends the Public Health Service Act by increasing communication and coordination with State trauma systems and requiring matching funds for subsequent fiscal years. The bill amends the Public Health Service Act by requiring matching funds for subsequent fiscal years. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include nationally recognized procedures for evaluation in designated programs. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include procedures for evaluation in designated trauma care programs, including coordination with state planning for trauma systems. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include trauma system planning coordination with state disaster and bioterrorism preparedness. Amendments in subsections (b) and (c) update years to 2004 for optimal care resources and evaluation procedures. In subsection (c), the Secretary will update the model plan in 2003. Section 1214(a) is amended to require submission of trauma plans and information by 2004. Section 1215(a)(1) is amended to restrict the use of payments. The Public Health Service Act is amended by replacing section 1216 with new requirements for reports by states, including the use of a semicolon instead of a period at the end. Section 1216 is reserved, Section 1222 is amended to change the year from 1995 to 2006, Section 1232(a) authorizes $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for 2005-2008, Section 1232(b)(2) is amended, and Part E of title XII is revised. "Part E--Miscellaneous Programs''; adding SEC. 1254. INSTITUTE OF MEDICINE STUDY. The Secretary will contract the Institute of Medicine or another entity to conduct a study on trauma care and research. The study will evaluate trauma care effectiveness, impact on patient outcomes, and identify research priorities and obstacles. The Secretary will contract a study on trauma care and research to evaluate effectiveness, patient outcomes, research priorities, and obstacles. The study will focus on identifying obstacles hindering trauma systems development, evaluating alternative strategies for trauma care organization, financing, and delivery, and assessing the role of trauma systems in mass casualty preparedness. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years, with an authorization of $750,000 for fiscal years 2004 and 2005. Residency training programs in emergency medicine will also be addressed. Section 1251(c) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to change the years referenced. Section 1252 is amended to remove the word "demonstration" from the section heading. Section 1261 is amended to focus on basic and clinical research on trauma, including prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of trauma-related injuries. The Director will establish a plan for the Program based on recommendations from the NIH Trauma Research Task Force. Changes include updating terminology from "acute head injury" to "traumatic brain injury" and "head" to "traumatic." Subsection (g) is removed, and subsections (h) and (i) are redesignated as (g) and (h) with updated years from 2001-2005 to 2004-2008. The Senate passed the bill on June 23, 2003. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
